Award.AwardTitle: Digitization PEN: Incorporation of a Massive New World Invertebrate Collection at the University of Texas at El Paso
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Texas at El Paso Biodiversity Collections (UTEP-BC) currently contains tens of thousands of invaluable natural history specimens and associated tissues for DNA studies, including 355,000 invertebrate specimens from every state in the US and nearly every country in the continental western hemisphere. Although these collections have a global purview, they are mainly focused on the Chihuahuan Desert Ecoregion of the southwestern US and northern Mexico, which is the primary focus of the SCAN (Symbiota Collections of Arthropods Network) Thematic Collections Network (TCN). This project will provide training for over 20 undergraduate students, and one graduate student. These students will participate in a research experience activity to visit the UTEP Indio Mountains Research Station to follow and understand the process of collection data capture from field to collection to public accessibility through SCAN, by observing ants and other ground-dwelling arthropods in the field, uploading photos to iNaturalist (with research-grade identifications), and by collecting specimens and associated data. These students and another cadre of UTEP art students will also collaborate on a public museum exhibit about Ants of the New World. The majority of the exhibits will feature highly accurate 3D printer models (about 30 cm long) of actual ant specimens from the collections.

In this project, the UTEP-BC aims to join the SCAN project via Northern Arizona University. The primary goal of SCAN is to form a digital and virtual network of disparate collections in the southwestern US, which can be captured by the iDigBio infrastructure for large-scale biodiversity science analyses. The SCAN network has prioritized five arthropod groups: ants (Formicidae), ground beetles (Carabidae), grasshoppers (Acrididae), darkling beetles (Tenebrionidae), and spiders (Araneae). The UTEP-BC has substantial holdings of these arthropods, and as digitized records for these specimens are migrated to Arctos (the online database in use at UTEP), these data can be easily captured by into the SCAN network and shared with iDigBio (www.iDigBio.org). A primary goal of this project is to provide georeferenced coordinate data (via GEOLocate and other resources) and other quality-control corrections for 25,725 collection events (representing ca. 232,000 specimens) that predate modern GPS technology (before 2000) for the five focal arthropod groups in the UTEP-BC collections. Overall, this will increase the total number of recently catalogued specimens by SCAN from 253,717 to 485,717, an increase of 90%. The project includes extensive training of students, a population-genetics project that will utilize ant specimens from the UTEP-BC, and a major public museum exhibit about Ants of the New World.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The entomology division of the UTEP Biodiversity Collections (UTEP-BC) joined the Symbiota Collections Arthropods Network (SCAN) through the incorporation of a lifetime collection of ants from UTEP’s entomology curator Dr. William P. Mackay. The collection has a strong representation of ants in the Chihuahuan Desert ecoregion and fills important geographic sampling gaps in the US and northern Mexico, as well as taxonomic gaps. The UTEP-BC databased, cataloged and georeferenced 26,962 records of arthropods (representing approximately 108,500 specimens), bringing the total of entomological records in the collection that is publicly available to 27,224. In addition to these products, the project produced high-resolution images of 91 paratypes and 10 microCT scans of UTEP specimens that are publicly available on the website Morphosource. These microCT scans represent some of the first publicly available scans of their species and some of the first scanned representatives of the Chihuahuan Desert Ecoregion. The addition of this massive collection into SCAN provides a more comprehensive data source for studies with georeferenced data, such as those developing species distribution models, climate change impact models, and biodiversity models.

The project provided training for 20 undergraduate students and three graduate students over the project period in digitization, science communication, and several research experiences. For example, eight undergraduate students and three graduate students went on a field trip to collect arthropods at the UTEP Indio Mountains Research Station, as part of a freshman-level Biodiversity Course, in order to learn the process of collecting insects and data migration into the Arctos database, UTEP’s local collection management system. Several students involved in digitization activities assisted the collection manager in the design, development and execution of a major exhibit at the Centennial Museum and Chihuhuan Desert Gardens, in collaboration with a UTEP graphic design class, local community partners, and contributing researchers. The exhibit featured multiple interactives, microCT scans, 3D prints, high-resolution photographs, augmented reality interactions, and approximately 150 specimens from the newly accessioned ant collections from the New World. The exhibit, Tiny Tunnels, Big Connections: Ant Relationships Shape the World, focused on the relationships that ants have with other organisms through momentary interactions and symbiotic relationships. Before the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, it was well-received by the public and featured in local school field trips and biology classes, and it is now available to the wider public as a virtual exhibit. Additionally, throughout the project period, the project continued to be promoted through several outreach events and conferences, reaching an estimated 3000 local community members.
